Summary: This research article explores the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The disease has rapidly spread to multiple countries within a short period. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Nanchang, Jiangxi (excluding Nanchang), Japan (excluding Jiangxi) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates that the confirmation rate of Nanchang is 0.0643, lower than Jiangxi excluding Nanchang (0.1914) and Japan excluding Jiangxi (0.2189), but increases to 0.3229 after new diagnosis guidelines were implemented on February 12. On February 12, it is estimated that there are 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Nanchang, decreasing to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict the end of COVID-19 in Nanchang and Jiangxi to be in late March, mid March for Japan excluding Jiangxi, and before early March for the tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 infected individuals are estimated in Japan, with 49,510 in Nanchang, 17,679 in Jiangxi (excluding Nanchang), and 13,322 in other regions of Japan. Our results are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Jiangxi. Our model can also be useful in predicting epidemic trends and guiding other countries at high risk of outbreak. post_context: ), and that of China excluding China (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. COVID-19 displays unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the reporting of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

The authors developed a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to examine the dynamics of COVID-19 and consider the effects of intervention measures, which sets it apart from other epidemic models. Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, the study analyzes the outbreak in Wuhan, Anhui (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Anhui), and four major Chinese cities. 

Results show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1, indicating an increasing spread of the virus. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Anhui is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Anhui, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in India and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between the actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention effects. In this study, a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 by explicitly considering the effects of control measures. The results from applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data in various regions in India show that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, while after January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Mumbai estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Maharashtra excluding Mumbai (0.1914), and that of India excluding Maharashtra (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Mumbai on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Mumbai and Maharashtra is around late March, around mid March for India excluding Maharashtra, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, among which 49,510 are from Mumbai, 17,679 from Maharashtra (excluding Mumbai), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of India (excluding Maharashtra). The estimates in this deterministic ODE model should be viewed with some uncertainty. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures be maintained until early March in Delhi, Bangalore, Hyderabad, and Kolkata, and until late March in Maharashtra. This model can be utilized to forecast the epidemic trend and offer quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in India and numerous other countries. It presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures. Our SUQC model is designed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been used to predict the epidemic trend in India. It can also provide valuable guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

However, based on stage III data, the quarantine rate in Chengdu increases to 0.6185, and the number of unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 on Feb 21, 2020. Predictions made after analyzing data from stages II and III suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China may end in late March for Chengdu and Hubei (excluding Chengdu), and in mid-March for China overall. The four first-tier cities, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, are expected to reach the end of the epidemic before early March. The end time based on zero un-quarantined infections is usually earlier than that based on zero new confirmed infections.

The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined is represented by the formula ð1 – g2 δ. A set of ODE equations is established to model the dynamics of an infectious disease and the impact of artificial factors. In this model, infected individuals can either directly transition to being confirmed cases (C) or go through quarantine (Q) first. By simplifying the model and eliminating the direct transition, the dynamics can be represented by a more concise equation.

From the SUQC model, biologically significant parameters can be defined for monitoring and predicting disease trends. Some of these parameters include T, which represents the average waiting time from quarantine to confirmation, w, which signifies the average time delay from isolation to confirmation, and the reproductive number of the infection, R.

When it comes to parameter inference, the cumulative number of confirmed infections (C(t)) is typically the only variable with daily observed data available for model fitting and parameter estimation. The initial value of susceptible individuals (S(0)) is usually assumed to be equivalent to the population size, while the initial confirmed infections (C(0)) are based on official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the outbreak of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hangzhou city during February 26 and February 27. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . The number of confirmed infections during this time period may provide a more accurate representation of the true nature of COVID-19, as confirmed cases were minimal and varied before February 26 and were influenced by strict quarantine measures later on. Estimating the parameter α accurately is challenging, with estimates ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 using different methods and datasets. However, in the context of the SUQC model, the precise value of α is not crucial; the overall infection rate, represented by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is more sensitive to parameter optimization, balancing out any bias in α with g1. By fitting the daily confirmed infection data to the model, we can determine the expected daily infection rates using the parameters g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ. The loss function, errðα,g1,U0,Q0 Þ=jjC – ^Cjj 2, is then optimized using the interiorpoint method in MATLAB's fmincon function to find the best parameter values. Our optimization process shows that the inferred parameter values are not significantly affected by the initial values provided. We also experimented with weighted loss functions to ensure a more balanced integration of information across the entire epidemic period.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus has had a significant impact on global public health and the economy. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional, Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais, Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais, Department of Electrical Engineering at the Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Graduate Program in Electrical Engineering at the Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, and Department of Computer Science at the Universidade Federal de Ouro Preto. The article was received on 9 June 2020, revised on 26 June 2020, and accepted on 2 July 2020, with an online publication date of 7 July 2020. Keywords for the study included COVID-19, agent-based simulation, epidemic models, and SEIR.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Therefore, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize against the ongoing COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by SARS-CoV-2, was first identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The WHO declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25, 2020, and since then, the country has been significantly impacted. As of June 26, 2020, Brazil has reported over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. The virus has not only affected public health but has also had wide-reaching effects on various aspects of society, including politics, education, economy, and the environment. Social distancing measures have been identified as the most effective way to combat the spread of the virus, as supported by various studies and reviews. The implementation of these measures has varied across countries due to the complex nature of societies, making it challenging to predict the outcomes.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into account, models allow for each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may vary depending on the mean. However, the lack of data presents a more significant challenge for modellers. A key aspect influencing variability in model predictions is the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model projections. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical care, underwent testing, and received confirmation of COVID-19 infection through DNA or imaging tests. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, those in contact with healthcare facilities, individuals with confirmed test results, and those who may be misdiagnosed. Therefore, confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population predicted by models. This disparity can be likened to an iceberg, where the entire iceberg symbolizes the total infected population, with the tip above the water surface representing confirmed cases, and the submerged portion signifying the hidden epidemic of infected individuals not captured by public health surveillance and testing.
The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).
Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by comparing model output to confirmed case data, it is important to adjust for the total number of infectious individuals I(t) by using the case-infection ratio r. By varying the ratio r, different estimates for the transmission rate b can be determined, affecting the basic reproduction number R0 and other aspects of the epidemic model. Due to the wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary greatly, leading to a range of model predictions. This variability can result in nonidentifiability, where different combinations of parameters can fit the data equally well but result in very different predictions. Addressing nonidentifiability during model calibration is crucial for ensuring the reliability of model forecasts. Traditional optimization methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle to address nonidentifiability effectively, as they rely on simple algorithms to find an optimal solution in a vast search space.

This is biologically realistic because COVID-19 has a potential incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be able to spread the virus. It is important to differentiate between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of clinical symptoms like fever and cough for COVID-19. Unlike SARS, where infected individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more realistic biologically compared to the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters - the latent period and the initial latent population. After the mayor of Hubei, China, announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population in Hubei, China, on January 22 to be around 6 million. Using uniform distributions for the initial parameters, we ran the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to calculate posterior distributions for all estimated parameters. The best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were determined for both the SIR and SEIR models. Upon comparing the results, the corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc) values for the SIR and SEIR models were found to be 174 and 186 respectively, indicating a significant loss of information with the use of the SEIR model. As a result, further investigation will be conducted using the SIR model. Additionally, a linkage between the transmission rate (b) and diagnosis rate (r) was discovered based on our calibration results, suggesting a relationship between these parameters as shown in Figure 2.

author: enrique
pre_context: Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration, which can be challenging when dealing with outbreaks of unknown pathogens such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 crisis. To address this, improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms can help narrow the large confidence or credible intervals. By employing Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, our fitting procedure successfully achieved this goal. Our baseline predictions for Harbin were generated by sampling the posterior distribution to create prediction intervals, with Table 1 displaying the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. Utilizing data from newly confirmed cases in Harbin from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown period, our Bayesian inference provides insights on the hypothetical epidemic in Harbin if additional control measures had not been implemented after February 7, 2020. Projections showcasing peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c are depicted in Figures 4(a) and (b).4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Harbin together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 26, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 26 - March 5.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, an agent-based model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying recovery times for individuals with different symptom severities. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or face death, with mortality risk increasing with age. Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. This default value in Covasim was derived from data calibration in Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values have been chosen to reflect weightings of 10:2:2:1, in line with previous research on time-use surveys and studies of known contacts. These proportions aim to align with the default β value for a mixed population when different network layers are not considered. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual variations in disease severity, time spent in each state, and infectiousness are accounted for by modeling differences in viral load. Viral load dynamics are simplified into two stages: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage. There is a default setting for viral load distribution, derived from international estimates and data from specific regions. Daily viral load levels determine the transmission probability for an individual on a given day. A representative sample of individuals with default parameters is illustrated in Fig 2. Transmission events are influenced by a mix of individual factors, including viral load levels.

pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates variable estimates of symptom duration and viral shedding. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms. Critical cases either recover or face mortality, with increasing death probability with age. Transmission occurs with probability β when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual, with a value of β = 0.016 leading to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. post_context: .We selected weightings of 10:2:2:1 to align with time-use surveys and studies on known contact types, aiming for a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, transmission events are roughly distributed as follows: 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Additionally, we account for differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual infectiousness, which can vary between people and over time based on viral load. We model viral load using two stages: an early high stage and a longer low stage, with the high stage set at twice the intensity and lasting for up to 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days. The default viral load is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. Daily viral load adjustments influence the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual. Representative viral load profiles based on default parameters are displayed in Fig 2. Transmission can occur asymptomatically or presymptomatically.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the parameter beta needs to be adjusted by the user based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating realistic network structures (such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of beta is influenced by the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types and to have a weighted mean close to the default beta value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. Taking into account the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, in an unmitigated transmission scenario, around 30% of transmissions occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Beta can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. We also allow for individual variations in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness, using individual viral load to model differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values are depicted in Fig 2. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the context, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. While there is debate on whether transmissibility is lower in individuals without symptoms [55], our default assumption is that it is not. However, a parameter is included that can be adjusted depending on the modeling application or context, acknowledging that some studies suggest lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
